channel.title: Reel Movement Blog
channel.description: This Blog is here to answer all your fitness needs. Do you live in the Brooklyn or queens area. Then shoot me and email and we can set up a complementary session. Do you have some fitness questions? Follow me on social media and ask away.

item.title: 3 Nutritional Tips to Build Muscle
item.description:
Designing a personalized nutrition program can be extremely complicated because everyone has various backgrounds, genders, and cultures. Which means there is no cookie cutter diet that fits everyone. So, creating a diet for anyone can be particularly challenging.

Nevertheless, there are some solid tips I can give you to build some solid muscle.

1. Calculate Your Energy Requirements

Everyone knows in order to build some lean muscle you are going to have to eat. I mean you are going to have to eat a lot, but the goal isn't to eat an exuberant amount of food. This is going to cause you to add plenty of body fat (I know you don't want that). So, lets build some lean muscle.

But How Much Calories Should I Take in

There are three things determine your daily energy requirement:

  • Basal metabolic rate (BMR)
  • Levels of physical activity
  • thermic effect of food

Now lets not get too scientific here

Your BMR is basically the amount of calories you need to live. Physical activity is obvious and it's the only one you have control over. The thermic effect of food is essentially the amount of calories it takes to digest and absorb food.

Follow along now because there is some math involved. I know, I'm sorry

we are going to calculate how may calories you need daily

Equation to determine BMR

(Males) 66.5 + (13.75 x weight in kg) + (5.003 x height in cm) - (6.775 x age)

(Females) 655.1 + (9.5663 x weight in kg) + (1.85 x height in cm) - (4.676 x age)

Now Multiply That by Your Physical Activity Level

  • 1.53 (Sedentary or light activity)
  • 1.76 (Active or moderate
  • 2.25 (Vigorous activity)

Ex. for 27 year old Male

weight= 200 lbs/2.2 = 92kg

Height = 72 inches x 2.54 = 183cm

plug that into the previous male equation = 2050 calories (BMR)

2050 x 1.76(activity level)= 3,608 calories per day

Ex.for 27 year old Female

weight= 120 lbs/2.2 = 54kg

Height = 63 inches x 2.54 = 160cm

plug that into the previous female equation = 1,162 calories (BMR)

1,162 x 1.53(activity level)= 2,614 calories per day

These are just some examples. Make sure you plug in the right numbers but now you have a good baseline to start and that is extremely important. Now you can make minor changes to create positive changes in your body.

2. Create a Caloric Surplus

Now lets start manipulating our caloric intake. The goal is to build muscle and in order to do that we need a caloric surplus. 1 pound of muscle is approximately 2,500 calories. So in order to put on some muscle you should increase your caloric intake by 300-500 calories per day. That means if we use our male client from above as an example, he should be consuming at least 3,908 calories per day.

3.Consume Adequate Protein to Build that Muscle

If you are trying to build some muscle The International Society of Sports Nutrition (ISSN) recommends taking in 1.5-2 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight. If we use our female example above that is 178 grams of protein a day, but this recommendation is meant for true strength and power athletes, which means they are training 6 days a week for a significant period of time. The recommended Dietary Allowance of protein is 0.8 to 1 gram per kilogram per day may not be enough to build some lean muscle. Ultimately it depends on your goals. If you are only training a moderate amount 1.2- 1.5 grams may be enough for you. Regardless, the quality of protein is important.

This is determined by its amino acid content. Proteins that contain all the essential amino acids (complete proteins) and in amounts sufficient enough to maintain protein synthesis. Some great examples are dairy products, eggs, meat and fish.

This article could just go on and on about just protein. Just remember to get a sufficient amount of protein and also to use supplementation when it becomes difficult to get it from only food alone.

“Remember train hard and train smart!”

Follow me on for more tips on improving your fitness

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce

item.title: 3 Diet Tips to Help You Shed That Body Fat
item.description:
First off “Good on you for taking an interest in being more health conscious”.I think it’s fairly reasonable to say mostly everyone’s fitness goals are to build as much lean muscle as possible and lose some body fat at the same time. Basically, we want to look good :) We want that summer body, all year round. Hey, don’t worry, I want to look good too.

The problem is, there is a ton of misleading information out there, especially, when it comes to nutrition. Your nutritional needs are based on your age, gender, lifestyle, level of activity, physical conditioning, and so much more.

You want that summer body? Good, I want you to have it, but lets do it in a healthy way that promotes a positive change in your life. Not in a way that has you dropping a macronutrient or an enormous amount of calories. Lets be smart!

With that said, here are 3 tips to help you shed some body fat.

1. CARBS, FAT, AND PROTEIN!

Do not get rid of any of these macronutrients! They are fundamental and your body requires them. Any diet that advocates eliminating any of these macronutrients is unhealthy and unrealistic. We need to make positive choices that become lifestyle changes.

With that being said, what should you do?

Simple, split each nutrient appropriately.

A good split to start with is 40% carbs, 30% fat, 30% protein ratio. Now, this can change depending on your activity level and other variables but it is a good place to start.

2. MAKE HEALTHY CHOICES

Here are Some Examples

Good Carbohydrates

  • Sweet Potatoes
  • Brown Rice
  • Quinoa
  • Fruits and Vegetables
  • Oatmeal

Good Protein

  • Chicken Breast
  • Tofu
  • Turkey
  • Eggs
  • Legumes

Good Fats

  • Almonds
  • Avocado
  • Olive Oil
  • Peanuts
  • Tuna

Clean eating is key

These are just a few healthy choices. The main thing is to be aware of what you put into your body

3. CREATE A CALORIC DEFICIT

This is the key here. If you burn more calories than you take in, you will inch closer to reaching the amount of body fat you desire. Couple this with some physical activity and you are golden. Remember, it's not carbs that are making you gain all that weight it is an excess of calories.

Keep track of what you put in your body and burn more calories than you take in.

These are 3 simple tips that will make a world of difference. Just be consistent and aware of what you put in your body.

“Remember train hard and train smart!”

Follow me on for more tips on improving your fitness

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce

item.title: Understanding the Roles that Muscles Play in the Body
item.description:
Muscles account for nearly half of the body’s weight and are of interest to many fields of health care and fitness. Regardless of whether or not your occupation is in the health industry, it is important to understand the various roles that muscles play throughout the body in order to aid you in your fitness journey. There are over 600 muscles in the human body. Of these, skeletal muscles make up 215 pairs. The muscles in the body have many properties and roles.

Properties of Muscle

  1. Excitability: The muscle’s sensitivity to chemical, electrical, and mechanical stimuli
  2. Contractility: The ability of the muscle to develop tension or internal force in response to stimuli
  3. Extensibility: The muscles ability to be passively and actively stretched beyond its normal resting length.
  4. Elasticity: The muscles ability to return to its resting length after it has been stretch passed its resting length

Role of Muscles

The main role of the muscle is movement. The muscle contracts and it simply attempts to pull the bones. The result is that the less stable bone moves toward the more stable bone which causes movement. Each muscle usually plays various roles.

Agonist

The agonist is the prime mover meaning it does the majority of work and causes the movement that is desired

Antagonist

The antagonist has the opposite effect of the agonist. It causes the opposing muscle to relax in order for the agonist to create movement

Stabilizers

The stabilizers surround the joint and provide support in order for the body segment to produce force and move

Synergist

Synergists assist the agonist in movement. They are also known as guiding muscles

Neutralizers

The neutralizers counteract the action of other muscles in order to prevent inappropriate muscle substitutions which can often lead to muscle imbalances.

These are not the only roles the muscles play in the body (for instance the muscles also provide 85% of one’s body heat) but they are important to know because they are the way the body creates movement and movement is what leads us to better health and wellness.

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce

item.title: Why is Interval Training so Popular?
item.description:
Interval training is really just one way to perform cardiovascular endurance training. Cardiovascular training is any type of exercise that improves the aerobic efficiency of the human body. Meaning, this type of training improves the ability of the lungs to take in oxygen, transfer it to the blood, and ultimately deliver that oxygen to the working muscles in order to aid in the production of energy. This type of exercise has many benefits, including the ability to perform cardiovascular training in a short amount of time and aiding in weight loss and management. A cardiovascular endurance program will aid weight loss as long as it is properly structured and accompanied by healthy eating habits.

There are many different methods of cardiovascular training: such long slow distance running, pace/tempo training, fartlek training, and interval training. Despite these entire different methods, interval training has become quite popular, but what is interval training?

Basically, interval training involves training at an intensity that is as close to your VO2max as possible. For example, an individual with a good cardiovascular base may perform a sprint at maximum capacity, about 85-95% their max heart rate, for a 30 seconds then go back down to 70-80 percent of their max heart rate for 1 minute. They may continue to cycle at this rate for about 5-15 minutes, which, is very intense on the body. This is not the only way to perform interval training rather it is just a simplistic method of breaking it down. The reason it has become so popular is because it can be done in a relatively short amount of time and it has the potential to burn more calories from fat which of course will aid in weight management.

Although, when an individual performs intervals it becomes relatively easy to over train the body with such an intense activity. So, ample rest and adequate nutritional intake is necessary between each session of interval training in order to ensure maximum performance and reduce the risk of injury.

Example of interval training program
sprint jog
1 minute / 20 sec

sprint

jog
1 minute / 20 sec

sprint

jog
1 minute / 20 sec

sprint

jog
1 minute / 20 sec

sprint

jog

4 minutes

3 minutes

2 minutes

1 minute

20 seconds

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce

item.title: PRINCIPLES OF TRAINING
item.description:
We all have been in a position where we want to get in better shape but we just have no idea where to begin. At Reel Movement you will not only train hard but you will also train smart. That means getting a better understanding of the human body and how it responds to exercise. To better understand how the body reacts to exercise we need to breakdown some basic principles of training.

Principle of overload

The body constantly adapts to the pressure that is exerted on it. If you intend to continue to see training adaptations you must place additional stress on the body. For example, you can increase the intensity of an exercise by decreasing rest time, adding additional weight, or progressing from a static movement to a dynamic one. It is important that you understand that the intensity should be raised progressively and cautiously in order to prevent overtraining.

Principle of Specificity

The body adapts to the specific demand placed on it. For, example you should not expect to lift heavier weights by running three miles. You should expect to improve at running three miles. If your goal is to improve your cardiovascular system than running is a good approach but if your goal is to improve lean muscle mass resistance training would be the best option. You should include different types of training because they all offer unique adaptations.

Principle of Individualization

We are all individuals and thus we have to take into account each person’s response to exercise. There is no exercise program that is one size fits all. Understanding your body is a key principle of training smart. For instance, you may need to remain at a lower intensity program for slightly longer than another individual or you may progress faster. Once you become conscious of your own body you will continue to progress safely and efficiently. “Remember train hard and train smart!”

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce

item.title: What is The Core and Why is it Important?
item.description:
Core training has become extremely popular over the past several years, but why is it so important and what are the potential benefits of training the core? The core musculature is not just made up of the rectus abdominus and the internal and external obliques, but a much more extensive network of muscles. The core is broken down into three systems.

The Local Stabilization System

The local core stabilizers are muscles that attach directly to the spine and aid in stability in between each vertebra. Some muscles that comprise the local stabilization system are the transverse abdominus, internal oblique, and the multifidus. This system overall contributes in increasing segmental spinal stability.

The Global Stabilization System

The muscles of the global stabilization system attach the pelvis to the spine. Some of the major muscles of this system include the quadratus lumborum, psoas major, and the external obliques. Its main function is to provide stability between the pelvis and the spine and transfer loads between the upper and lower extremities.

The Movement System

The muscles of this system attach the spine and/or pelvis to the extremities. The movement systems primary muscles are the latissimus dorsi, hip flexors, hamstrings, and quadriceps. When it comes to the core the movement system provides dynamic stabilization when the body is performing functional activities.

The core ultimately provides stabilization throughout the spine and hips allowing for optimum joint movement. A strengthened core reduces the risk of injury, improves function and performance, and improves neuromuscular control and stability. A good core program focuses on function and movement rather than just quantity. So, in your training regime be sure include some core exercises and watch how much more your performance improves

Founder and CEO of Reel Movement

Daniel Ponce
